ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a ton of grammatical skills, plenty of pronunciation, and a load of Kanji from this class.
A grasp of higher-level grammar points such as comparisons, and thinking conditionally.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this class involve the engagement between student and material during class time. I do believe the workload is a bit much, but I also think it is necessary for learning such a complex language.

Strengths: Great course for beginning to intermediate Japanese students with food pace and rewarding homework. Weakness: Attendance and participation not strictly enforced; many students show up late or dont prepare for class. They suffer no repercussions, and detract from learning in group conversations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If someone is actually serious about learning Japanese, this class is ESSENTIAL. Otherwise, it does pose a ton of work.
Yes. I really feel like Ive gotten quite close to an intuitive grasp of the grammar itself, rather than memorizing phrases or vocab as Ive done in other language courses.
